Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the wall of the site office—6:55 p.m. My shift ended at seven, but the foreman had just reminded us that the sweep-up had to be thorough tonight. Dust and debris littered my section, and I knew if I left it half-done, I’d hear about it tomorrow. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, vibrating with the familiar alarm I’d set for every Thursday evening. It was time for my weekly call home. My stepmom always waited for it, and Dad would ask if I was eating well, if I was safe. They said it made them feel connected, like I was still part of the family even though I’d moved out. I could already picture my stepmom’s voice, a little anxious if I was late, wondering if something was wrong. I stared at the broom in my hand, then at the phone, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in. If I called now, I’d have to leave the site messy and risk the foreman’s anger. If I stayed to clean, I’d break the promise I made to my family. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the two worlds that needed me.
